tables.title: Outcomes and Impact of the French Revolution

rows.description: The ideas of liberty and democratic rights spread from France to the rest of Europe, influencing modern laws and the abolition of feudal systems
The Convention legislated to free all slaves in French overseas possessions in 1794, although Napoleon reintroduced slavery ten years later, which was finally abolished in 1848
The notions of equality and freedom influenced anti-colonial movements in India, China, Africa, and South America, contributing to the spread of these ideas globally.
The revolutionary wars caused economic difficulties and societal changes, leading to the rise of political clubs and actions advocating for extended rights beyond the richer sections of society.
The Third Estate declared themselves a National Assembly, intending to draft a constitution that would limit the monarch's powers. This phase was marked by democratic aspirations and reforms

Under Robespierre's rule, the government issued strict laws, instituted price controls, and practiced widespread use of the guillotine. This phase was characterized by radical policies and mass executions

Following the Reign of Terror, the Directory was established, leading to a period of political stability. This phase saw significant social and educational reforms, although political struggles continued

rows.beliefs: Wanted a nation which tolerated all religions, opposed uncontrolled power of dynastic rulers, argued for a representative, elected parliamentary government.

Wanted a nation in which government was based on the majority of a country’s population, supported women’s suffragette movements, opposed the privileges of great landowners and wealthy factory owners.
Initially opposed to the idea of change, but by the nineteenth century, they accepted that some change was inevitable and believed in a slow process of change.
